author: By Kevin Draper
title: What Sports Fans Need to Know About a New Streaming Service
description: The joint venture announced by Disney, Fox and Warner Bros. Discovery will offer a lot, but it may not be enough on its own for serious fans.
content: Disney, Fox and Warner Bros. Discovery announced on Tuesday that they would join together and sell access to all of the sports they televised through a new streaming service. It will be available this fall, but many other details, like price or who would run the service, are not yet known.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
title: U.S. Debt on Pace to Top $54 Trillion Over Next 10 Years
description: Congressional Budget Office projections released on Wednesday said a growing economy and recent spending cuts had slowed deficits.
content: The United States is on a pace to add nearly $19 trillion to its national debt over the next decade as the mounting costs of an aging population and higher interest expenses continue to weigh on the nation’s fiscal outlook, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: tedious
description: This word has appeared in 133 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word tedious has appeared in 133 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 14 in “A Few Words About Netflix’s Success: Vivid. Snappy. Tags.” by John Koblin:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith and Dani Blum
title: New Report Raises Concerns About Long Covid in Children
description: The condition is less prevalent among children than adults, but symptoms can disrupt their schoolwork and social lives.
content: A large analysis published Wednesday in the journal Pediatrics underscores the toll long Covid can take on children, in some cases leading to neurological, gastrointestinal, cardiovascular and behavioral symptoms in the months after an acute infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Haley Outvoted in Nevada Primary by ‘None of These Candidates,’ Without Trump on the Ballot
description: Ms. Haley ran essentially unopposed in the primary, which awards no delegates. The former president will compete in Thursday’s caucuses.
content: Nikki Haley was outvoted in Nevada’s Republican presidential primary by a “None of These Candidates” option on the ballot on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, an embarrassment in a contest in which she faced no direct competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Crew Member Working on Marvel’s ‘Wonder Man’ Dies in Fall
description: The worker fell from a catwalk at Radford Studios early Tuesday, officials said.
content: A crew member working on the set of Marvel Studios’ “Wonder Man” TV series at Radford Studios in Los Angeles died on Tuesday after falling from a catwalk, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Taylor Swift Heading to Disney+ and ‘Moana’ Sequel to Theaters
description: The pop star’s hit “Eras Tour” concert film hits the streaming service next month, part of the company’s attempt to revitalize its entertainment lineup.
content: Disney is deploying Taylor Swift and Moana as part of a campaign to revitalize its entertainment lineup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: How Chanel No. 5 Became a Necklace
description: The accessory — which doubles as a diamond ring — takes its inspiration from the design of the iconic perfume bottle.
content: In 1920, following the successful launch of her couture house in Biarritz, France, and her subsequent move to Paris’s Rue Cambon, where she opened her flagship boutique, Gabrielle “Coco” Chanel decided to create her first fragrance. She commissioned the French Russian perfumer Ernest Beaux to develop “a woman’s perfume, with a woman’s scent” — which, unlike most single-note options of the era, had a bold floral composition. Beaux imported exotic ingredients from around the world, concocting a mix of more than 80 different notes, including jasmine and May rose harvested from Grasse, France; ylang-ylang flowers from Madagascar; Brazilian tonka beans; and sandalwood. Months later, he presented Chanel with an array of aromatic vials, and she chose the one labeled five. When Beaux asked her what she’d call the perfume, she said, “I present my dress collections on May 5, the fifth day of the fifth month of the year, and so we will let it keep the number it has, and this number will bring it good luck.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: American Cities Aren’t Doomed After All
description: The urban “doom loop” seems to have come to a halt.
content: For a year or two, as first-wave pandemic panic gave way to a more generalized perception of ragged social disorder, it was hard to read or talk about the plight of American cities without encountering the chilling phrase “doom loop.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: Many Transgender Americans Face Stigma and Financial Hardship, Survey Finds
description: The survey of more than 92,000 transgender and nonbinary Americans also found that the vast majority were satisfied with their decision to transition.
content: Transgender and nonbinary Americans experience stark rates of unemployment and harassment, according to the largest survey of their life experiences to date. The data reflect a longstanding pattern of discrimination at a time when states across the country have passed laws restricting their health care, bathroom access and participation in sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Loudin
title: The Ultimate Workout for Pickleball Lovers
description: If pickleball is your main form of exercise, you may need to augment it. Here are the moves you need to add to age well and avoid injury.
content: For the third year in a row, pickleball has been the nation’s fastest-growing sport. Selena Gomez “dinks” on the regular, as does Jenna Bush Hager. Even Michael Phelps has traded swimming paddles for pickleball ones.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Full Transcript of the Democrats’ 2020 Platform on Immigration
description: The platform, called “Creating a 21st century immigration system,” shows how much more pro-immigration the party has become.
content: In today’s Morning newsletter, David Leonhardt recommended reading the Democratic Party’s immigration platform. A full transcript of it, from the party’s website, follows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: A Conversation With the History Curator of the California African American Museum
description: Susan D. Anderson talks about the forgotten history of California’s earliest Black residents.
content: Black residents make up a relatively small share of California’s population. But the state is so big that it’s still a significant number of people: Roughly one in 20 Black Americans lives in the state, according to the Public Policy Institute of California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: A Legal Outsider, an Offbeat Theory and the Fate of the 2024 Election
description: When the Supreme Court considers whether Donald J. Trump is barred from appearing on Colorado’s ballot, a professor’s scholarship, long relegated to the fringes, will take center stage.
content: In the world of American legal scholarship, Seth Barrett Tillman is an outsider in more ways than one. An associate professor at a university in Ireland, he has put forward unusual interpretations of the meaning of the U.S. Constitution that for years have largely gone ignored — if not outright dismissed as crackpot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj and Anindito Mukherjee
title: Who Created Butter Chicken? India’s Great Curry Clash.
description: A court has been asked to solve a bitter dispute between two families who have very different accounts of the origins of a dish beloved around the world.
content: In 1947, two men, both named Kundan, fled Peshawar during the bloody partition that carved Pakistan out of British India. They landed in Delhi and soon became partners in a restaurant called Moti Mahal serving food from the Punjab region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Education Dept. Investigates Claims of Discrimination Against Palestinian Students at Harvard
description: The Office for Civil Rights of the U.S. Education Department is looking into the allegations after a complaint from a Muslim advocacy group.
content: The U.S. Education Department said on Tuesday that it had opened an investigation into Harvard over whether it failed to protect Palestinian, Muslim and Arab students and their supporters from harassment, threats and intimidation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall and Adam Sella
title: Israel Chooses a Eurovision Act as Boycott Campaigns Swirl
description: Eden Golan will represent the country in May, in a contest that looks set to be overshadowed by the war in Gaza.
content: The singing contest’s glitzy lights and glittering dresses were supposed to be a respite after another depressing, hostage-filled news day on Israeli TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Forceful Opinion Repudiates Claim That Trump Can’t Be Charged in Election Case
description: The unanimous ruling, by a panel of appeals court judges appointed by presidents of both parties, systematically took apart the immunity claim.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s claim that he was immune from being prosecuted for any crimes he committed while trying to stay in office after losing the 2020 election was always a long shot. But in an opinion on Tuesday eviscerating his assertion, three federal appeals court judges portrayed his position as not only wrong on the law but also repellent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Johnson Stumbles, Deepening Republican Disarray and His Own Challenges
description: Little more than 100 days into his tenure, the speaker who was handed an impossible job has only made it more difficult for himself, baffling his colleagues.
content: When one of the most stinging defeats of his short tenure arrived on Tuesday, Speaker Mike Johnson had put himself front and center in the House chamber, standing in front of the speaker’s ceremonial chair on the upper tier of the rostrum to gavel it down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gerald Narciso
title: It’s a Big Weekend for Football. And for Fancy Jets.
description: Around 1,000 private aircraft are expected at Las Vegas airports for the Super Bowl. It matters for climate change, and maybe for Taylor Swift, too.
content: Nothing about Las Vegas is measured in moderation. The fluorescent buildings are towering and intentionally bright. Around casino floors, at pool parties and on the Vegas Strip, throngs of tourists daily play chicken with their alcohol tolerance levels and credit card limits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: At This California Radio Station, the Call Letters Say It All
description: KGAY in Palm Springs is geared toward Gen X and older gay men who enjoy Rihanna but still worship Donna Summer.
content: Fog clouded the San Jacinto Mountains recently as Brad Fuhr approached the headquarters of KGAY, a radio station in an undistinguished Palm Springs, California, strip mall. Fuhr, the station’s chief executive, was tuned to KGAY in his all-electric Volvo, and the morning’s soundtrack included “Bad of the Heart,” George Lamond’s 1990 freestyle cri de coeur about getting dumped, and “Lucky Star,” Madonna’s 1983 dance hit of bouncy adoration.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Star’s Range Only Starts at the 3-Point Arc
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 7, 2024.
content: “She’s shown a lot of families that are raising a young girl who’s really wired with that passion. This is the female athlete. Allow them to be.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Da’Vine Joy Randolph: Major Prizes, Major Attention, Major Unease
description: The “Holdovers” star sometimes feels overwhelmed by the glare of the spotlight. “In a very otherworldly way, my entire world has changed.”
content: The “Holdovers” star Da’Vine Joy Randolph has had a charmed run through awards season so far: Considered the favorite for the supporting actress Oscar, she has already taken the Golden Globe, Critics Choice Award and prestigious trophies from both the New York Film Critics Circle and Los Angeles Film Critics Association.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Natalie Kitroeff, Carlos Prieto, Clare Toeniskoetter, Will Reid, Lexie Diao, Michael Benoist, Rowan Niemisto, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: El Salvador Decimated Gangs. But at What Cost?
description: What was one of the world’s most violent countries has become incredibly safe. It has transformed more troubling ways, too.
content: El Salvador has experienced a remarkable transformation. What had once been one of the most violent countries in the world has become incredibly safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: Al Green, in Hospital Garb, Delivers Vote to Kill Mayorkas Impeachment
description: The Democrat from Texas had undergone abdominal surgery but rushed to the Capitol because he said the vote was “personal.”
content: With the final minutes for the vote dwindling, the House watched intently on Tuesday night to see whether any more Republicans would defect on the resolution to impeach Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: How Earth Might Have Turned Into a Snowball
description: A team of scientists thinks the planet may have been thrust into its longest ice age because less gas leaked out of volcanoes.
content: Around 717 million years ago, Earth’s humid landscapes and roiling blue waters transformed into a frigid, barren world. Scientists nicknamed this stage of geological history, and others like it, Snowball Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Federico Rios
title: Terrorized by Gangs, Ecuador Embraces the Hard-Line ‘Noboa Way’
description: President Daniel Noboa’s new war on gangs has widespread support in a nation overwhelmed by violence. But experts warn it could endanger civil liberties.
content: Since Ecuador’s president declared war on gangs last month, soldiers with assault rifles have flooded the streets of Guayaquil, a sprawling Pacific Coast city that has been an epicenter of the nation’s yearslong descent into violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Lincoln Center’s Leader, Henry Timms, to Depart After Five Years
description: After guiding the arts organization through the pandemic and completing the renovation of David Geffen Hall, he is leaving to lead the Brunswick Group.
content: Henry Timms, who guided Lincoln Center through the turmoil of the pandemic and helped complete the $550 million renovation of David Geffen Hall, will step down as its leader this summer after five years, he announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Woman Who Caused Fatal Buggy Crash Tried to Have Twin Take Blame, Authorities Say
description: A sheriff deputy’s tape recorder captured a conversation between the two sisters that raised questions about their story, according to a complaint.
content: A Minnesota woman whose S.U.V. struck a horse and buggy last fall, killing two children and injuring two others, tried to trick the authorities into believing that her twin sister was the driver, according to court documents.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 7, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Feb. 7, 2024.
content: An article on Sunday about wildfires in Chile misstated the locations of Viña del Mar and Valparaíso in relation to Santiago. They are northwest, not northeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Joao Silva
title: Playing Soccer in $1.50 Sandals That Even Gucci Wants to Copy
description: In Ivory Coast, lêkê are the preferred footwear for amateur games and almost everything else.
content: The wealthy pros of Ivory Coast’s national soccer team were resting in their luxury hotel last week, preparing for a match in Africa’s biggest tournament, when Yaya Camara sprinted onto a dusty lot and began fizzing one pass after another to his friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom and Amy Julia Harris
title: New York Spends Millions on Mental Health Street Teams. Do They Work?
description: The city has poured funding into a program to aid severely mentally ill people while doing little to ensure it was getting results, an audit shows.
content: New York City has poured tens of millions of dollars into a program to treat severely mentally ill people on the streets and in the subways for nearly a decade without ensuring that it was operating effectively, according to an audit made public on Wednesday by the city comptroller.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Plan Reining In Police Response to Protests Can Go Ahead, Judge Rules
description: A federal judge rejected a last-ditch effort by the Police Benevolent Association to stop a deal that would dramatically alter how officers respond to demonstrations.
content: New York City can proceed with an agreement to overhaul how the Police Department handles demonstrations, a federal judge ruled on Wednesday, rejecting arguments from the police officers’ union that the changes would endanger officers and the public.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Carnegie Hall’s New Season: What We Want to Hear
description: Our critics choose highlights, including concerts featuring Mitsuko Uchida as a Perspectives artist and Gabriela Ortiz as the hall’s composer in residence.
content: The Latino experience will be a focus of Carnegie Hall’s coming season, the presenter’s leadership announced on Wednesday, with a festival inside and beyond the hall’s walls called “Nuestros Sonidos” (“Our Sounds”) and a slate of concerts featuring artists with ties to Latin America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Right-Wing Congressman to Run for Senate in Montana, Igniting G.O.P. Fight
description: As Republicans try to take down Senator Jon Tester, a Democrat, and win back control of the chamber, Representative Matt Rosendale is set to enter the race and start a primary clash.
content: Representative Matt Rosendale of Montana is expected to announce a campaign for Senate as soon as this weekend, torching plans from top Republican officials to avoid a bruising primary battle in a state that many in the party view as their best chance to win back control of the chamber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Rome’s Ancient Grandeur Towers Anew With a Copy of a Colossus
description: A 1:1 facsimile of the statue of Constantine shows how modern technology can help recreate the past, and offers new ideas for scholarship.
content: It may not be authentic, exactly, or very old at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Rosenbloom
title: Make Sparks Fly at 5 Romantic Getaways
description: Hoping to slip away with your sweetheart this month? Check out one of these intimate spots where you can sip wine, stroll, stargaze and enjoy a candlelit Valentine’s Day dinner.
content: Whether you want to stroll along a beach or cuddle beside a fire, these getaways prove that romantic accommodations come in many forms, including a new luxury resort in Mexico, an estate in the English countryside, just-opened cabins for stargazing in the Catskills, a farmhouse in California wine country, and hotels with February discounts on the coast of Maine. No matter where you go, you’ll find Valentine’s Day dinner menus and activities for two, like couples’ massages and private yoga sessions — though many rooms at these properties are so plush, you just might decide to ditch your plans and stay in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Tortured Poets’ or Poets? Taylor Swift Meets the Apostrophe Police
description: Grammarians wonder: Should there be an apostrophe in “The Tortured Poets Department”?
content: When Taylor Swift announced at the Grammys that the title of her new album would be “The Tortured Poets Department,” what was your reaction?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: One-Pot Hainanese Chicken and Rice for Harried Weeknights
description: Just because it’s Wednesday doesn’t mean you can’t have tender, gingery chicken and rice with a sizzled scallion sauce.
content: The classic method for Hainanese chicken rice, which has you gently poach a whole bird and use the resulting broth to cook the rice, makes for a flavor cycle where nothing is lost. In her smart and deeply comforting take, Genevieve Ko streamlines the cycle further by cooking the chicken and the rice in the same pot, making it a perfect meal for any given Wednesday. Even more, instead of the three sauces that are traditionally offered alongside, she opts for a single killer one, a pungent mix of ginger and scallions warmed by a drizzle of sizzling oil. With its silky chicken, gingery rice and aromatic, bright green sauce, this is a vibrant, satisfying meal that will elevate your week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Giorgia Meloni Solidifies Her Credentials in Europe
description: The Italian prime minister helped persuade the Hungarian leader, Viktor Orban, to go along with a landmark fund for Ukraine. It was a big moment for Europe. And for her.
content: The Hungarian prime minister, Viktor Orban, was isolated, the sole holdout to a landmark European Union fund for Ukraine worth billions. As pressure mounted on him on the eve of an emergency E.U. summit last week, he needed someone to talk to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Dairy Products Are Linked to Listeria Outbreak
description: Rizo-López Foods recalled its dairy products this week, as officials linked some of them to an outbreak that has sickened 26 people since 2014.
content: A listeria outbreak that has sickened at least 26 people in 11 states since 2014 has been linked to queso fresco and cotija cheese made by Rizo-López Foods, a California-based food supplier, federal public health officials said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: A Critic Who Strives to Hit the Right Note
description: Zachary Woolfe, the classical music critic for The New York Times, shared how he endeavors to make his writing accessible to both neophytes and experts.
content: Zachary Woolfe grew up in a musical household. His parents were big fans of Bob Dylan and Joni Mitchell, and often played their music throughout their Long Island, N.Y., home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Aston Barrett, 77, Bass-Playing Force With Bob Marley and Wailers, Dies
description: Known by his nickname, Family Man, he was the group’s musical director, crafting the hypnotic rhythms and melodies that elevated reggae to global acclaim.
content: Aston Barrett, who as the bass player and musical director for the Wailers — both with Bob Marley and for decades after the singer’s death in 1981 — crafted the hypnotic rhythms and complex melodies that helped elevate reggae to international acclaim, died on Saturday in Miami. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: A court rejects Donald Trump’s immunity claim.
content: A federal appeals court denied former President Donald Trump’s claim that he was immune from prosecution for plotting to overturn the 2020 U.S. election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: Iraq Hosts Both U.S. and Iranian-Backed Forces. It’s Getting Tense.
description: As Iranian-backed groups and American forces, both of which have bases in Iraq, lock horns around the Mideast, things are becoming uncomfortable for the Iraqi government.
content: For years, Iraq has managed to pull off an unlikely balancing act, allowing armed forces tied to both the United States and Iran, an American nemesis, to operate on its soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Benjamin Weiser
title: Informant in Menendez Bribery Investigation Made Secret Recordings
description: A new legal filing in the case against Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, refers to recordings from a “confidential source.”
content: When Senator Robert Menendez was charged with conspiring to act as an agent of Egypt, prosecutors included a photograph of a small dinner meeting he held with his soon-to-be wife and three people with ties to Egypt at a steakhouse in Washington, D.C.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2024 Grammys, Dissected: Taylor, Miley, SZA, Tracy, Joni and More
description: Was this the year the awards got it correct?
content: At Sunday’s Grammy Awards, Taylor Swift won album of the year for “Midnights” and, for good measure, announced a new album, “The Tortured Poets Department,” due in April. Other big winners included Victoria Monét, Phoebe Bridgers (and boygenius), Killer Mike, Miley Cyrus and Billie Eilish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: 9 Key Revelations in Maui’s First Review of the Lahaina Inferno
description: Officials provided the first comprehensive look at where the 100 victims of the Aug. 8 wildfire were found.
content: Six months after a firestorm destroyed the town of Lahaina, Hawaii, a detailed new report on the tragedy reveals that a large number of victims died along a single street — a stark indication of the ferocity of the blaze that swept through the historic island town, killing 100 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney Has ‘Turned the Corner’ After a Strong Quarter, Iger Says
description: The company, facing pressure from activist investors, surpassed expectations for earnings and slowed its streaming losses.
content: Robert A. Iger has insisted for months that his turnaround plan for Disney was working. But distinct proof has been elusive, and investors, as evidenced by the company’s underperforming stock price and multiple proxy campaigns by activists for board seats, have been hesitant to buy in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Prince William Is Back at Work, Facing a New Normal
description: Returning to royal duties after his wife’s surgery and the news of King Charles’s cancer, the heir to the throne will confront new demands on his time.
content: Prince William, the heir to the British throne, stepped back onto the public stage Wednesday, trying to project a steely sense of normalcy, two days after the announcement that his father, King Charles III, had been struck by cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Harvard Is Accused of Obstructing House Antisemitism Inquiry
description: Representative Virginia Foxx said Harvard had provided a “limited and dilatory” response to a House committee investigation. She threatened to file a subpoena to force Harvard to submit more documents.
content: A congressional committee examining campus antisemitism accused Harvard on Wednesday of obstructing its investigation, saying that the university failed to submit documents it had requested while flooding the committee with publicly available pages containing “inexplicable” redactions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Donovan
title: A Stunning Soufflé Is an Act of Love
description: Soufflés have a reputation for being precious or fanciful. But they can also be deeply satisfying.
content: You can go your whole life without having a single experience with something, and then quite suddenly, it is everywhere in your world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Dreier
title: Confronted With Child Labor in the U.S., Companies Move to Crack Down
description: McDonald’s, Costco and other major brands say they are stepping up efforts to keep minors from the grueling, often dangerous work that goes into their products.
content: Many major U.S. companies — including some of the country’s biggest consumer brands — say they are taking steps to eliminate child labor in their domestic supply chains amid revelations that children are working throughout American manufacturing and food production.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Why Did My Birth Son Invite Me to a Wedding and Then Seat Me in Siberia?
description: Reunited with her son after half a century, a reader feels slighted by her seat at a family wedding, where her son’s wife had already made her feel less than welcome.
content: I am a birth mother whose son found me seven years ago, when I was 70 and he was 49. I gave him up for adoption as an infant; his adoptive mother is deceased. He called me Mom from Day 1, and we felt an immediate heart connection. It has been a roller coaster of intense emotions. Unfortunately, his wife wrote me a letter saying she does not recognize me as his mother and wants nothing to do with me. Still, my son and I have developed a loving relationship over texts and phone calls. (We live 3,000 miles apart.) So, I was thrilled to be invited to his stepson’s wedding — though also nervous, given his wife’s letter. My son assured me I would be seated with his siblings, but I was placed at a distant table with his friend. I was also excluded from a family outing and the photos posted on Facebook. It felt like a punch to the heart. But my son doesn’t acknowledge any responsibility for my hurt. Did he gaslight me?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russian Strikes Hit Ukrainian Cities at a Tense Time for Kyiv
description: The attacks killed at least five people, officials said, as Ukraine raises pleas for more American aid and President Volodymyr Zelensky considers changes in his administration.
content: Missiles streaked into Kyiv early Wednesday in a Russian attack that killed at least five people, according to local officials, jolted residents awake with air alarms and explosions, and ignited a fire that sent plumes of smoke billowing over the Ukrainian capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Son Refuses to Play With an Outcast. Does That Make Him a Bully?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how a parent might address social exclusion among a group of schoolchildren.
content: Our son plays with a group of children, ages 5 to 12, on our block. One boy is regularly excluded. He doesn’t play well with others, is verbally and physically aggressive and, I’ll admit as a parent, a pretty annoying kid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Showing Off Rock-Solid Technique and Some Erotic Acrobatics
description: Philadanco returns to New York with four premieres that highlight the dancers’ skills without revealing much deeper artistry.
content: Philadanco is a company in transition. A few years ago, Joan Myers Brown, the pathbreaking institution builder who founded the Philadelphia Dance Company in 1970, stepped aside, installing Kim Y. Bears-Bailey as artistic director. But when the troupe returned to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday for the first time since the handover, it looked pretty much the same as ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: The United States Has Been a Bulwark for Ukraine. What Happens if Support Collapses?
description: American officials concede there is nothing on the horizon that could match the power of a new, $60 billion congressional appropriation to support its war against Russian aggression.
content: A year ago, when Washington and much of Europe were still awash in optimism that Ukraine was on the verge of repelling Russia from its territory, it seemed inconceivable that the United States would turn its back on the victim of Vladimir V. Putin’s aggression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: When It Comes to Dating, Ambition Might Matter More Than Politics
description: Toward a grand theory of modern young love.
content: I read through all 274 responses to a questionnaire I put out about how politics affects the dating lives of Americans under 30, and I took note of the fact that quite a few respondents used economic terminology when describing their romantic experiences. The term “scarcity,” in particular, came up more than once as a factor in dating experiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $450,000 Homes in Virginia, Massachusetts and Ohio
description: A Carpenter Gothic-style home in Irvington, a cottage in the Berkshires and a two-bedroom brick house in Columbus.
content: Just three hours outside the Washington metro area, with easy access to the Rappahannock River and Chesapeake Bay, Irvington has become a popular second-home and retirement destination. This house is in a small community less than five minutes by car from the town’s main thoroughfare, where there are several cafes, a flower shop and a museum devoted to the area’s maritime history. The Tides Inn, a waterfront hotel and spa, is less than two miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Senate Moved to Salvage Ukraine Aid
description: Also, a U.S. strike killed an Iranian-backed militia commander. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Democrats in the Senate are pushing to advance a package that would send billions of dollars in aid to Ukraine and Israel, after Republicans blocked similar legislation that paired the foreign aid with stringent border security measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: A Mom’s Conviction Offers Prosecutors a New Tactic in Mass Shooting Cases
description: The guilty verdict in Michigan against the mother of a school shooter will reverberate in prosecutors’ offices around the country. But don’t expect a flood of similar cases, experts say.
content: The guilty verdict on Tuesday against the mother of a Michigan teenager who murdered four students in 2021 in the state’s deadliest school shooting is likely to ripple across the country’s legal landscape as prosecutors find themselves weighing a new way to seek justice in mass shootings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal, Genevieve Glatsky and Hamed Aleaziz
title: Deportation Flights From the U.S. to Venezuela in Limbo
description: Flights sending Venezuelans back to their homeland have not taken off for two weeks. The move could be a setback to President Biden’s effort to tackle a migration surge.
content: When deportation flights from the United States to Venezuela resumed last fall after four years, it was a move meant to show that President Biden was aggressively tackling the record numbers of crossings at the U.S. southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M.D. Rodrigues
title: The Best Laughs on ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’ Have Always Been Larry’s Own
description: For almost 25 years, Larry David has charmed us with his knowing mischief and endearing jolliness.
content: As the creator and star of “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” Larry David has been ambling in and out of view for almost 25 years, playing a version of himself whose odyssey is now winding to a close: This month, the show began its 12th and final season, concluding a run that started in the last days of the Clinton administration. David has also, in a more colloquial sense, played himself. “Curb” sends up his celebrity, rendering him a tetchy caricature whose showbiz success has granted him time enough at last to enjoy the pettier things in life. This “Larry” is a gadfly who goads others, and himself, into fits of rancor. Yet he’s also gregarious, the type for whom every car ride is an occasion to discuss, say, the serenity of gardeners or a possible link between the words “yoga” and “yogurt.” In “Curb,” discomfort has always been made tolerable by such frivolity, and by the knowing mischief of David’s performance. At its heart is the signature of David’s screen persona: his own irrepressible laughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Missing Helicopter Found in California, but Search Continues for 5 Marines
description: The helicopter, which was scheduled to land in San Diego on Tuesday, went missing overnight, the authorities said.
content: A search and rescue operation located a Marine Corps military helicopter on Wednesday that went missing in a snowy and mountainous area east of San Diego, but the authorities said they were still looking for five Marines who were on board the aircraft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Akhil Reed Amar
title: The Supreme Court Should Get Out of the Insurrection Business
description: Who is to decide whether Donald Trump must answer for Jan. 6? The Constitution provides the answer.
content: The Supreme Court will hear arguments on Thursday about whether Colorado may keep Donald Trump off the presidential ballot because of the storming of the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The justices should seek a ruling that is originalist, modest and respectful of America’s democratic federalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Nevada’s Struggling Economy Could Hold a Key to 2024
description: Democrats say the state’s economy is getting better, while Republicans argue it’s getting worse. Which message resonates more could decide the pivotal battleground state this fall.
content: Nevada has the worst unemployment rate in the country, gas and grocery prices are still among the nation’s highest, and the cost of housing here has soared. President Biden’s policies are squarely to blame, Republicans argue, and former President Donald J. Trump will fix it if voters return him to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: When ‘Giants’ Roam the Museum Halls
description: The Brooklyn Museum exhibits art works collected by the musical superstars Swizz Beatz and Alicia Keys — and it makes a show of the collectors, too.
content: Right in the middle of the exhibition “Giants: Art from the Dean Collection of Swizz Beatz and Alicia Keys,” which opens Saturday at the Brooklyn Museum, is Kehinde Wiley’s 25-foot-long 2008 painting “Femme Piquée par un Serpent.” Showing a Black man in snappy but casual dress reclined in a distinctively twisted position, with a background of Wiley’s signature flowers, it borrows both title and pose from an 1847 marble sculpture by Auguste Clésinger. What you think of it really depends on what you’re asking for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Florida Court Weighs Ballot Measure to Allow Abortion ‘Before Viability’
description: Several justices pushed back on Wednesday against arguments that the language of the proposed constitutional amendment was too broad and would deceive voters.
content: The Florida Supreme Court seemed reluctant on Wednesday to block a proposed measure protecting abortion rights from appearing on the November ballot, even though several members of the conservative-leaning court questioned whether the measure’s language made clear its potentially sweeping effects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Prince Harry Ends U.K. Trip Without Meeting Prince William
description: On a whirlwind trip to London, Harry met briefly with his father, King Charles III, who has cancer, but did not visit his older brother, the heir to the throne.
content: Prince Harry did not meet with his brother, Prince William, during a roughly 24-hour trip to Britain after Buckingham Palace announced that their father had cancer, an indication that relations between the siblings remain tense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Republicans Against Border Enforcement
description: Many in the party have decided to oppose a bipartisan plan for the border.
content: The United States has had a porous border with Mexico for decades, and the situation has worsened in the past few years, with more than 10,000 people entering the U.S. on some days. Many then remain for years, even without a visa or citizenship. Mayors, governors, and immigration experts — as well as voters — have long urged Congress to fix the problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Cheers the Rejection of Trump’s Immunity Claim
description: “It was a devastating moment for Trump, especially when Melania started clapping,” Jimmy Kimmel said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: She Ordered an Ashtray and Got a Can of Tuna
description: Return fraud is a rampant problem for both shoppers and retailers — and the mishaps often make for viral videos on TikTok.
content: Bailey Cormier was browsing the Saks Fifth Avenue website one evening when she decided to buy a blue and white, porcelain ashtray, for $275.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Senate Bogs Down on Ukraine and Israel Aid After G.O.P. Blocks Border Deal
description: Democrats promised a Thursday vote on a stand-alone bill, stripped of immigration measures, with $60.1 billion for Ukraine, $14.1 billion for Israel and $10 billion in humanitarian aid for civilians of global crises.
content: The Senate bogged down on Wednesday over a bill to send tens of billions of dollars to Ukraine and Israel after Senate Republicans blocked a compromise that would have paired the aid with stringent border security measures, adjourning without moving forward on the emergency national security spending package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Administration Toughens Limits on Deadly Air Pollution
description: The E.P.A. says the new rule will prevent 4,500 premature deaths annually. Industry leaders are expected to challenge the regulation, saying it will harm the economy.
content: The Environmental Protection Agency on Wednesday tightened limits on fine industrial particles, one of the most common and deadliest forms of air pollution, for the first time in a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Ashes Were Given to His Family. But He Wasn’t Dead.
description: Tyler Chase, 22, was living in transitional housing in Portland, Ore., when the authorities misidentified a body as his and cremated it.
content: The first sign that Tyler Chase got that he might be dead came at a convenience store. He had food stamps, but his benefit card didn’t work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Real Estate Crisis Looming Over Banks
description: A year after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, investors are fearing for regional lenders saddled with a mountain of souring commercial mortgages.
content: The sell-off in regional bank stocks looks set to worsen on Wednesday, after Moody’s cut New York Community Bancorp’s credit rating to junk status.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Beatles Conquered New York 60 Years Ago Today
description: A photographer who was at Kennedy Airport when the band landed there in 1964 went on to have an illustrious career.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look back at a week in New York that clinched the Beatles’ place in American popular culture. We’ll also find out why Mayor Eric Adams says the city needs $4.6 billion to pay for half of the yearly costs related to the influx of migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Perfect Days’ Review: Hanging On
description: Directed by Wim Wenders, this Oscar-nominated Japanese drama gently excavates the life of a toilet cleaner, and the shadows that lurk inside.
content: Pay attention to the shadows in “Perfect Days.” Pay attention also to the trees, to the ways Hirayama (Koji Yakusho) looks at them. They’re as much a character in the story as he is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisa Gabbert
title: Perfection and Precision in a Poet’s Miniature Worlds
description: The poems in Mary Jo Bang’s latest collection, “A Film in Which I Play Everyone,” are full of pleasure, color, sound and light — but also torment.
content: “O God, I could be bounded in a nutshell and count myself a king of infinite space, were it not that I have bad dreams.” Thus speaks Hamlet, Act II, Scene 2. Rosencrantz has just suggested to the prince that Denmark is “too narrow for your mind.” This may be why I always picture, at this juncture in the play, half a walnut shell upside down: a makeshift model of a human brain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Strugatz
title: No, Michael Cera Is Not the Mastermind Behind CeraVe
description: So what’s with the elaborate online marketing campaign implying otherwise?
content: For the last three weeks, videos of Michael Cera have circulated online, claiming that the actor is the founder of the skin care brand CeraVe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: How Robots Learned to Write So Well
description: “Literary Theory for Robots,” by Dennis Yi Tenen, a software engineer turned literature professor, shows how the “intelligence” in artificial intelligence is irreducibly human.
content: In “Literary Theory for Robots,” Dennis Yi Tenen’s playful new book on artificial intelligence and how computers learned to write, one of his most potent examples arrives in the form of a tiny mistake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Some Fall Out of Vogue. She Jumped.
description: Gabriella Karefa-Johnson on surviving Ye, quitting Condé Nast and speaking her mind.
content: When Gabriella Karefa-Johnson, the fashion editor-personality who became famous as the first Black woman to style a Vogue cover (in 2021) and even more famous after she got into a social media brouhaha with Kanye West, was interviewing for her first big fashion job at Vogue, she ended up, not surprisingly, in front of Anna Wintour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Republican Dysfunction, and Mom Convicted in School Shooting Case
description: Plus, the Apple Vision Pro hype.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: How Ford’s F-150 Lightning, Once in Hot Demand, Lost Its Luster
description: Some buyers said the electric Lightning did not meet expectations, and Ford has slashed its production plans for the pickup because sales are lagging.
content: In July Michael Puglia drove home with what seemed like the coolest vehicle he’d ever own — a Ford F-150 Lightning electric pickup truck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Should Be Done to Protect Children Online?
description: At a congressional hearing, senators accused tech executives of harming their platforms’ youngest users. How concerned are you about online safety?
content: How concerned are you about the dangers of social media and the internet? In your opinion, are technology companies doing enough to protect children online? If not, should Congress step in and pass legislation to address the problem?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: It Was Once Pakistan’s Military Stronghold. Now Even It Has Had Enough.
description: The mounting frustration with the military establishment is a stark shift in Punjab, the country’s most populous and politically important province.
content: As they head to the polls this week, residents in Pakistan’s most populous and affluent province are fed up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘The Connector’ Review: When Fake News Was All the Rage
description: An Off Broadway musical about the sins of journalistic fabrication might benefit from more make-believe.
content: If you’re even a little sensitive to signs of sociopathy, you’d peg Ethan Dobson right away. Someone at the start of a promising career in journalism who is so aggressively flattering and greasily evasive, with a snap-on, snakelike, aw-shucks smile, has got to have a scheme up his sleeve. Or rather, in Ethan’s case, a dangerous bunch of lies in his pocket.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Conviction of a School Shooter’s Mother
description: Readers agree that Jennifer Crumbley shared responsibility for her son’s rampage. Also: Donald Trump and immunity; a failed impeachment; Vivek Ramaswamy.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Alissa J. Rubin
title: U.S. Strike in Baghdad Kills Iranian-Backed Militia Commander
description: The killing of a leader of Kata’ib Hezbollah continued a series of strikes in retaliation for attacks on U.S. troops in the region, including one that killed three Americans in Jordan.
content: A U.S. Special Operations retaliatory drone strike in the Iraqi capital on Wednesday killed a senior leader of a militia that U.S. officials blame for recent attacks on American personnel, the Pentagon said, following up on President Biden’s promise that the response to a slew of attacks by Shiite militias would continue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Raise a Big Stink
description: Make some noise for Daniel Mauer’s musical crossword.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: At 116, She Has Outlived Generations of Loved Ones. But Her Entire Town Has Become Family.
description: When the nation’s oldest person has a birthday, a California community makes sure to celebrate.
content: When Edith Ceccarelli was born in February 1908, Theodore Roosevelt was president, Oklahoma had just become the nation’s 46th state and women did not yet have the right to vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Special Counsel in Biden Documents Case Is Expected to Release Report Soon
description: Most of the work by Robert K. Hur appears to have wrapped up after President Biden sat down with investigators in October, according to people in Mr. Biden’s orbit.
content: Robert K. Hur, the special counsel investigating President Biden’s mishandling of documents retained from his vice presidency, is expected to release his report soon, according to people with knowledge of the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: What Does King Charles’s Cancer Diagnosis Mean for Prince William?
description: How life may change for the Prince of Wales and his younger brother, Harry, who flew from Los Angeles to visit their father.
content: Less than two weeks after King Charles III was admitted to a London hospital to be treated for an enlarged prostate, Buckingham Palace disclosed that tests had revealed “a form of cancer.” As Charles has been “advised by doctors to postpone public-facing duties,” many expected other members of the royal family to step up to the plate. So what does the news mean for Charles’s two sons, William and Harry?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Is Trump’s MAGA ‘Superpower’ Actually His Kryptonite?
description: Biden isn’t the only one who wants to know.
content: What does President Biden have to do to catch up to Donald Trump?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Simon Romero
title: For First Time in Two Decades, U.S. Buys More From Mexico Than China
description: The United States bought more goods from Mexico than China in 2023 for the first time in 20 years, evidence of how much global trade patterns have shifted.
content: In the depths of the pandemic, as global supply chains buckled and the cost of shipping a container from China soared nearly twentyfold, Marco Villarreal spied an opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Eckholm
title: When Did New York’s Streets Get So Hollow?
description: The city is rewriting its antiquated zoning code. We should seize the chance to create a metropolis of opportunity that evolves with the times.
content: Over the past decade, there has been much hand-wringing about New York’s puzzling empty storefront problem, with vacancy rates sitting north of 15 percent last fall in some of the city’s most celebrated areas. How did streets, from the East to the West Village, once home to the urbanist Jane Jacobs, a champion of the city’s neighborhoods, become so hollow?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: After Humiliating Result in Nevada, Haley Goes After Her Own Party
description: The former South Carolina governor, who was outvoted by “None of These Candidates” after Donald Trump declined to participate in the primary, criticized the state of the Republican Party.
content: After perhaps her worst result in her Republican primary campaign — finishing second to “None of These Candidates” in Nevada’s primary, in which the front-runner, former President Donald J. Trump, was not competing — Nikki Haley unloaded on her own party, painting the day not as bad for her, but for Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Nayeri
title: Untangling the Pasts of Slavery, Colonialism and Art
description: A new exhibition at the Royal Academy of Arts in London looks at how artists of earlier centuries depicted enslaved people — and how contemporary creators do.
content: Two and a half centuries after its creation, the Royal Academy of Arts in London — an artist-and-architect-led institution that is a bastion of the British establishment — is embracing inclusivity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darren Incorvaia
title: A Two-Ton Lifeguard That Saved a Young Pup
description: In an unlikely act of altruism observed two years ago, a male elephant seal prevented a younger animal from drowning.
content: Male elephant seals are not known for their paternal instincts. While splayed out on the beach during the breeding season, these far-from-gentle giants focus on mating with females and fighting other males. As they hustle their two tons of bulk around the colony in pursuit of these goals, “they’ll run over pups” without hesitation, crushing even their own offspring, said Daniel Costa, an ecologist at the University of California, Santa Cruz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: New York Times Co. Adds 300,000 Digital Subscribers in Quarter
description: At the end of the year, The Times had 10.36 million subscribers, 9.7 million of them digital-only.
content: The New York Times Company added 300,000 paid digital subscribers in the fourth quarter of 2023, the company said on Wednesday, helping to push annual revenue for digital subscriptions above $1 billion for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
title: Hungary and E.U. Lock Horns, This Time Over Foreign-Interference Law
description: The European Commission began a disciplinary procedure over recent legislation that focuses on contacts between foreigners and Hungarians.
content: Just days after a major showdown between the European Union and Hungary over aid to Ukraine, the European Commission on Wednesday announced it was opening a new disciplinary procedure against the Hungarian government over recently passed legislation that focuses on interactions deemed subversive between foreigners and Hungarians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: As His Border Deal Dies, a G.O.P. Senator Laments the Forces Against It
description: Senator James Lankford pleaded with his party not to let politics trump policy, recounting opposition including a right-wing media personality who vowed to do “whatever I can to destroy you.”
content: About an hour before Republicans sank a breakthrough border security compromise on Wednesday, Senator James Lankford, the bill’s lead negotiator, rose on the Senate floor to plead with members of his own party to take the deal that they had demanded — and that he had delivered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Commercial Real Estate Is in Trouble. Here’s What to Focus On.
description: Is the Fed chair too blasé?
content: When Jerome Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, appeared on “60 Minutes” this past weekend, he said he wasn’t super-worried about the risk of a banking crisis triggered by defaults on office buildings and downtown retail. While acknowledging that the future is uncertain, he said that “it appears to be a manageable problem” for the biggest banks. He said “we’re working” with some smaller and regional banks that have “concentrated exposures in these areas that are challenged.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel
title: The Evolving Watchdog Group Behind the Ballot Challenge to Trump
description: Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, or CREW, is among the avowedly nonpartisan groups under pressure from donors to take more aggressively political stances.
content: No matter how the Supreme Court rules on Donald J. Trump’s challenge to a Colorado court ruling barring him from the state’s primary ballot, the case has already been a win for one group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump’s Border Intervention Gives Biden a Chance to Shift from Defense to Offense
description: After three years under fire for record illegal migration on his watch, the president blames his predecessor for preventing action to secure the southwestern border.
content: When President Biden agreed to bipartisan talks on border legislation last fall, Democratic strategists hoped a deal might take the issue off the table for his re-election campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Barkan
title: How Oct. 7 Drove a Wedge Into the Democratic Party
description: Members of Congress, and candidates for their seats, have been drawn into bitter political clashes over the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
content: When George Santos, the indicted fabulist, was expelled from Congress in December, Nassau County Republicans scrambled to hunt up a new nominee. Santos was a catastrophe, but he had also flipped a New York Democratic stronghold, and party leaders wanted the best of him — the charisma, the conservatism and the history-making potential — with none of the debilitating drawbacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Ex-College President Accuses Board Chair of Sexually Harassing His Wife
description: The former president of Seton Hall University sued the school, saying it responded to his complaints with “gaslighting.”
content: The former president of Seton Hall University in New Jersey sued the school on Monday, accusing its former chairman of trying to intimidate him and sexually harassing his wife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Biden Sails to Victory in Nevada’s Primary as He Heads Toward Nomination
description: The president easily won the Democratic race in a state that will be a top battleground in November, just days after dominating his challengers in South Carolina.
content: President Biden coasted to victory on Tuesday in Nevada’s Democratic presidential primary election, carrying his party’s second recognized nominating contest against token opposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Shane Goldmacher, Jonathan Swan and Annie Karni
title: Ronna McDaniel, R.N.C. Chairwoman, Plans to Step Down
description: Donald Trump is likely to back a supporter of his false claims of election fraud, Michael Whatley, the head of the North Carolina G.O.P., to replace her.
content: The chairwoman of the Republican National Committee, Ronna McDaniel, has told former President Donald J. Trump she is planning to step down shortly after the South Carolina primary on Feb. 24, according to two people familiar with the plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love John Coltrane
description: Coltrane changed the game in American music a few times over. Here’s a guided tour to his career, courtesy of 15 musicians, scholars, poets, writers and other experts.
content: Yes, it’s time for this series to focus on John Coltrane — perhaps the most sanctified musician in the whole Black American tradition, who other artists sometimes refer to simply as “St. John.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By César Cuauhtémoc García Hernández
title: This Immigration Bill Was Never Going to Fix the Border
description: If more money would stop people coming to America, we would have paid for the solution years ago.
content: On Sunday, lawmakers in Washington released the first major bipartisan bill to reform immigration policy in a decade. The Senate may vote on the proposal, a $118 billion plan that includes $20 billion aimed at bolstering immigration enforcement, as early as Wednesday, but the likelihood that it reaches the president’s desk is slim. The House speaker, Mike Johnson, described it as “dead on arrival” in his chamber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: A.I.-Generated Faces
description: Can you spot the real ones from the digital fakes?
content: Tools powered by artificial intelligence can create lifelike images of people who do not exist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman
title: Election Office Blasts in Pakistan Kill at Least 22 a Day Before Vote
description: Attacks against activities linked to the national elections, including the targeting of candidates, have surged during campaign season.
content: Two separate explosions outside election offices in an insurgency-hit area of Pakistan killed at least 22 people and wounded several others on Wednesday, officials said, a deadly reminder of the deteriorating security situation in the country as it heads into national elections on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Vision Pro Review: Apple’s First Headset Lacks Polish and Purpose
description: Billed as the future of computing, the $3,500 goggles can’t replace a laptop for work. At times, wearing them also made our columnist feel nauseated.
content: About 17 years ago, Steve Jobs took the stage at a San Francisco convention center and said he was introducing three products: an iPod, a phone and an internet browser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: For a Ukrainian Gardener, Flowers Offer a Way Forward
description: When war came to her country, Alla Olkhovska had been planning to open a rare-plants nursery. Now her Clematis seeds have an international following.
content: The Clematis that delight Alla Olkhovska the most among the 120 or so types she grows are not the familiar, large-flowered hybrids, as extravagantly beautiful as they are. It’s the small, less frequently grown species — the ones whose common names often include the phrase “leather flower,” many of them native to the Southeastern United States — that have stolen her heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Landreth
title: Ai Weiwei’s ‘Zodiac’ Is a Mystical Memory Tour
description: Like a cosmological comic, the artist’s new ‘graphic memoir’ entwines recalled experience with legend and imagination.
content: As the Year of the Dragon dawns, the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei has released “Zodiac,” a “graphic memoir” of scenes from his career — both real (hanging with Allen Ginsberg, the O.G. of Beat poets, in 1980s Greenwich Village) and imagined (debating Xi Jinping, China’s paramount leader). Each chapter frames the artist’s take on traditional beliefs about the characteristics humans share with the 12 animals of the Chinese lunar calendar. Gianluca Costantini’s intricate line drawings pair with Elettra Stamboulis’s comic-bubble text to help expand Ai’s lifelong campaign for free expression to a new medium for a new generation. Ai spoke with Jonathan Landreth about parents and parenting, punk rock and the passage of time, all via video chat last week from Berlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Finding Fresh Talent for Fancy Watches
description: Louis Vuitton gathered up-and-coming watchmakers in Paris this week with its first watch prize and a party hosted by the youngest Arnault scion.
content: Watches make up only a small fraction of sales for LVMH, the biggest luxury goods empire in the world. The group is far better known for Louis Vuitton leather handbags and Moët Champagne. But lately, with Swiss watch exports reaching record highs and growing interest in fancy timepieces from a new generation of wealthy global consumers, LVMH is showing heightened focus on its fine watchmaking business, which includes TAG Heuer, Hublot and Zenith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Berlinger
title: Jennifer Lawrence, Kendall Jenner and Taylor Swift Have Eaten Here
description: Sushi Park, a modest-looking L.A. restaurant located in an unassuming strip mall, has become an unlikely hangout spot.
content: Sushi Park opened nearly two decades ago in a tucked-away corner on the second floor of a nondescript strip mall along the Sunset Strip in Los Angeles. It’s an unlikely celebrity hangout, but a scan of paparazzi images shows that the rococo railing in front of the restaurant has become a mainstay of the celebrity press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Buoro
title: Read Your Way Through Lagos
description: Like many Nigerians, the novelist Stephen Buoro has been deeply influenced by the exquisite bedlam of Lagos, a megacity of extremes. Here, he defines the books that make sense of the chaos.
content: Lagos is an experience of a lifetime. The city will enchant and wreck you. The bedlam. The 15-minute journeys that stretch to five hours because of traffic jams. The multitudes everywhere you turn, each individual fizzing with hope and energy and stories, each unfazed by the maladies of living here — crumbling infrastructure, an oppressive kleptocratic government, the daily whiff of disasters brewing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Thursday Briefing: The Stakes of Pakistan’s Elections
description: Also, U.S. aid to Ukraine stalls and a fight over the origins of butter chicken.
content: Pakistan is holding its national elections today. Experts say they will be among the least credible in the country’s history. Days before the vote, Imran Khan, who was ousted as prime minister in 2022, was sentenced to a total of 24 years in prison in two separate verdicts. The sentences were widely seen as part of a military-led campaign to sideline Khan’s political party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Settler Colonialism: A Guide for the Sincere
description: A popular academic theory merits closer scrutiny.
content: A former colleague of mine liked to say that there are certain ideas that vanish in the presence of thought. Among those ideas is settler colonialism — or rather, the invidious, hypocritical and historically illiterate way in which it is often denounced in anti-Israel polemics and protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurtis Lee and Brendan George Ko
title: ‘My Everything — Gone in a Matter of Moments’
description: Six months after the Maui wildfire, hundreds of businesses remain closed, and questions linger about how much a local economy should rely on tourism.
content: Twisted and charred aluminum mixed with shards of glass still lines the floor of the industrial warehouse where Victoria Martocci once operated her scuba diving business. After a wildfire tore through West Maui, all that remained of her 36-foot boat, the Extended Horizons II, were a pair of engines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Marks and Vishakha Darbha
title: Still Baffled by Trump’s Appeal? Listen to This.
description: He was never just a presidential candidate.
content: Donald Trump’s popularity has long confounded those opposed to him — he lost after his first presidential term, has been accused of sexual harassment and assault multiple times and faces 91 felony counts in four criminal cases. Despite this, he continues to captivate millions. In this audio essay, Anna Marks, an Opinion staff editor, argues that we have it all wrong — to understand Trump’s appeal, we need to see him not as a politician, but as a pop star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Two Cases Aim to Cut Off China and Iran From U.S. Technology
description: In one case, material stolen from a private company would help the development of technology to track ballistic and hypersonic missiles, U.S. officials said.
content: The U.S. government announced charges in two separate cases on Wednesday aimed at enforcing laws blocking the transfer of critical technologies, part of a broader campaign to hamper military efforts and weapons production in rival countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and David E. Sanger
title: Sweden Closes Investigation of Pipeline Blasts, but Stays Silent on Cause
description: The natural-gas connection was sabotaged in September 2022, seven months after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, prompting rampant speculation about who was to blame.
content: After investigators delved into a series of undersea explosions that blew apart the Nord Stream natural gas pipelines linking Russia to Western Europe in fall 2022, intelligence agencies came to a general agreement: The evidence pointed toward pro-Ukraine forces, even if the question of who might have been directing them remained a mystery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Mary Todd Lincoln, Thwarted Cabaret Star? That’s Cole Escola’s Take.
description: “Oh, Mary!,” which follows a boozing, romance-starved first lady, is the latest entertainment about the Lincolns, illustrating their staying power as irreverent genre figures.
content: It’s hard to pin down the moment in “Oh, Mary!,” a comedy about Mary Todd Lincoln, that will send Lincoln scholars and purists into apoplexy. It could be when the first lady disastrously auditions for a role in “Our American Cousin,” the play at which John Wilkes Booth would later shoot her husband on April 14, 1865. Or when the deeply closeted Lincoln is orally pleasured at his desk. Maybe the puke-drinking scene?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Joan Lader Keeps Broadway in Tune
description: “She saved my career,” Patti LuPone said of this indispensable vocal therapist and coach whose clients include Madonna and Billy Porter.
content: For 41 years, Joan Lader has rented a slender studio apartment just west of Union Square in Manhattan. Through its door, a narrow entryway leads to a doll-size bathroom and an efficiency kitchen. In the main space, where a visitor might expect to find a bed, Lader has arranged the instruments of her trade — a piano, a keyboard, balance balls, straws, a box of tissues, a skeleton in a jaunty hat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Nikki Haley Still Isn’t Quitting
description: The electoral math is tough when the Republican base seems determined to nominate Trump again.
content: Nikki Haley lost badly in Iowa and New Hampshire. In Nevada on Tuesday, she ran unopposed in an irrelevant primary and finished behind “None of These Candidates.” But she is still trying to broaden voters’ imagination of what’s possible, both for her prospects in the 2024 Republican presidential primary, and for the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Elon Musk Is Funding Ex-‘Mandalorian’ Actress’s Suit Against Disney
description: Gina Carano accused Disney and Lucasfilm of discrimination when they dropped her after she posted baseless conspiracy theories and right-wing views on social media.
content: Elon Musk poked the Walt Disney Company anew on Tuesday by agreeing to fund a wrongful-termination lawsuit filed by the “Mandalorian” actress Gina Carano.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gershom Gorenberg
title: Israel’s Fragile Democratic Future
description: Israel’s Supreme Court narrowly shut down Benjamin Netanyahu’s efforts to overhaul the judiciary, but the concern remains.
content: In normal times, thousands of people would have poured into the streets to celebrate the Israeli Supreme Court’s decision to strike down a central piece of the Netanyahu government’s plan to cripple democracy. The so called reform had triggered immense, constant protests for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Adam Rasgon and Michael Levenson
title: Hamas Gives ‘Positive’ Reply to Gaza Truce Plan, but Odds Remain Murky
description: U.S. and Qatari leaders hinted at progress in talks for a truce and the release of hostages, but it remains unclear how Israel, determined to crush Hamas, will respond to the group’s counteroffer.
content: Hamas has answered a proposal that could halt fighting in the Gaza Strip, release the remaining hostages there and allow more aid to reach desperate Palestinians, U.S. and Qatari leaders said on Tuesday, offering a hint of wary optimism after four brutal months of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: New York Reimagined Subsidized Housing. What Happened?
description: Via Verde aspired to serve as a model of beautiful, sustainable subsidized housing. A decade later, our critic finds that a building can change minds, but maybe not systems.
content: “A beacon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Super Bowl Foods by the Numbers
description: A look at how much pizza, wings and processed cheese Americans will consume this Sunday.
content: A look at how much pizza, wings and processed cheese Americans will consume this Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: What’s in Our Queue? Mahjong and More
description: I’m the Shanghai bureau chief for The New York Times. Here are five things I’ve been reading, playing, listening to and watching.
content: I’m the Shanghai bureau chief for The New York Times. Here are five things I’ve been reading, playing, listening to and watching.

author: By Jazmine Ulloa, Claire Hogan and Brent McDonald
title: Haley Prepares for Fierce Showdown With Trump in South Carolina
description: Jazmine Ulloa, a Times reporter, analyzes the campaign strategy of Nikki Haley, as she focuses efforts on her home state of South Carolina.
content: Jazmine Ulloa, a Times reporter, analyzes the campaign strategy of Nikki Haley, as she focuses efforts on her home state of South Carolina.

author: By Shawn Paik
title: The Debate Over Butter Chicken’s Origins
description: The celebrated Indian dish combines tandoori chicken with a creamy curry made with tomatoes, butter and spices.
content: The celebrated Indian dish combines tandoori chicken with a creamy curry made with tomatoes, butter and spices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen, Karen Hanley and James Surdam
title: Testing Apple’s Vision Pro
description: Our personal tech columnist tries Apple’s new Vision Pro and is less than impressed.
content: Our personal tech columnist tries Apple’s new Vision Pro and is less than impressed.
